docs.snippet: Jens and Lars Rasmussen, the brothers who created what has become Google Maps, have spent the last couple of years holed up in Google's offices in Sydney, Australia, dreaming up a new tool for communicating over the Web. On Thursday, at a Google c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jens and Lars Rasmussen, the brothers who created what has become Google Maps, have spent the last couple of years holed up in Google's offices in Sydney, Australia, dreaming up a new tool for communicating over the Web. On Thursday, at a Google conference for developers in San Francisco, they showcased the result: Google Wave. Google Wave is an application running in a Web browser that creates a shared online desktop where two or more users can interact easily. They can exchange messages as they would in e-mail or instant messaging conversation. They can share and edit documents that include text, images and graphics. They can also drag and drop simple applications called widgets into a Wave to, for example, play a game together.

headline.main: Google Combines Chat and E-Mail

docs.snippet: At its London office across the street from the bustling Victoria station, Google is using both high-tech and low-tech strategies to minimize its environmental impact....
docs.lead_paragraph: At Google's London office, across the street from the bustling Victoria station, high- and low-tech strategies are used to minimize its environmental impact. As an example, an enormous video-conference network across Google's 119 global offices has minimized the need for extensive inter-office travel and helped Google weather the current economic storm as other companies learn to adapt to business travel cutbacks.

headline.main: Getting Greener at Google's London Office

docs.abstract: At its London office across the street from the bustling Victoria station, Google is using both high-tech and low-tech strategies to minimize its environmental impact.

docs.lead_paragraph: Digg has generated a fair amount of drama over the years as it has tried to work out how to turn a profit. The San Francisco company, which lets people vote on the news stories that interest them, has tried at various times running ads from Google, the ad network Federated Media and Microsoft, and it recently began to reach out to advertisers directly.

headline.main: Digg Will Charge Less for Ads Its Users Like

docs.snippet: THE NEWS Bing, the new search service by Microsoft, made its debut last week as the company unleashed an advertising campaign estimated to cost $80 million to $100 million to establish the service as an alternative to Google.     BEHIND THE NEWS T...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE NEWS Bing, the new search service by Microsoft, made its debut last week as the company unleashed an advertising campaign estimated to cost $80 million to $100 million to establish the service as an alternative to Google. BEHIND THE NEWS Taking on Google, which holds about 64 percent of the search market in the United States, is a tall order. Even after spending billions on search services over the years, Microsoft has a scant 8 percent of the market, according to comScore, a research company. But Microsoft is hoping Bing will evoke the ''aha'' moment that punctuates a successful search and become part of the popular lexicon, as in, ''Why don't you Bing it?''

headline.main: Debuts | May 31 -- June 6

docs.snippet: Professor Motwani taught computer science at Stanford and was a mentor to many Silicon Valley start-ups....
docs.lead_paragraph: Rajeev Motwani, a Stanford computer science professor and an investor in technology start-ups who mentored many young Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, including the founders of Google, died on Friday at his home in Atherton, Calif. He was 47. The cause of death was being investigated, said Robert Foucrault, the San Mateo County coroner. Mr. Motwani was found dead at the bottom of his backyard swimming pool Friday morning, said Lt. Mike Guerra of the Atherton Police Department. There was no evidence of a crime at the scene, he said.

headline.main: Rajeev Motwani, a Professor Behind Google, Dies at 47

docs.lead_paragraph: The Times' Media Decoder blog has a post today with Local interest, about America Online's purchase of Patch Media Corp., which was also described on the Millburn Patch site here. Proving that all news is indeed local, one Maplewood blogger, Kirk Petersen, was quickly on the story, as was the All Things Digital blog, which posted internal memos about the sale. AOL's CEO, Tim Armstrong, was described as the principal investor in Patch, a collection of websites covering Maplewood, Millburn and South Orange, among other towns, back when he was an executive for Google.

headline.main: New Owner for Patch

docs.snippet: How a Web tweak of Google Maps can make it more useful for joggers and walkers....
docs.lead_paragraph: Don't have a physical pedometer but still want to measure your distance -- and even count calories burned on your walks or jogs around town? Created by a marathon runner, the Gmap Pedometer lets you draw out your route on a Google map. The Gmap Pedometer then shows you the total mileage from the starting to the ending points -- and calories used to cover the distance.

headline.main: Q & A Tip of the Week: Using Google Maps to Burn Calories

docs.snippet: Google added Persian to its automatic translation service, saying it hoped to help people inside and outside of Iran communicate and stay abreast of events in that country....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google said Friday that it was adding Persian, or Farsi, to the languages it is able to translate to and from automatically through the Google Translate service. The company said it hoped the service, which it rushed because of the turmoil in Iran, would be used by people inside and outside of that country to communicate and stay abreast of events. The service is available at http://translate.google.com.

headline.main: Amid Iran Turmoil, Google Adds Persian to Translation Service

docs.abstract: Google added Persian to its automatic translation service, saying it hoped to help people inside and outside of Iran communicate and stay abreast of events in that country.

In the past, she wrote, she had agreed with me that Apple was being too cute in its disclosures, but now that he was about to take a six-month leave, things were different.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week I asked readers to pick up the phone and help me test a feature in Google's new phone call management service that automatically transcribes voice mail messages. I encouraged creativity, and I got a lot. People called up and left all kinds of stuff for Google's speech-recognition algorithms to puzzle over.

docs.snippet: Faced with increasing government scrutiny, Google must convince regulators that is a relatively small company, one that is vulnerable to competition....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google handles roughly two-thirds of all Internet searches. It owns the largest online video site, YouTube, which is more than 10 times more popular than its nearest competitor. And last year, Google sold nearly $22 billion in advertising, more than any media company in the world.

headline.main: Google Argues That It Really Isn't So Big

docs.lead_paragraph: YouTube confirmed on Tuesday that Steve Chen, a co-founder and most recently YouTube's chief technology officer, was no longer working at the company. Mr. Chen left some time ago to work on unspecified engineering projects at its parent, Google.

headline.main: YouTube Co-Founder Switches to Google

docs.abstract: Steve Chen, YouTube's founder, left the online video site to work at parent company Google.

docs.snippet: Analysts say Internet companies and ad agencies have no choice but to work together to develop ways to make money from digital media....
docs.lead_paragraph: Advertising agencies and Internet companies once viewed each other as foes, but are now coming together to harness the potential for online advertising. Like many other segments, online ad spending has slowed from its previous breakneck pace during the deep recession, forcing companies to devise new ways to chase fewer dollars. Last week, Eric E. Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, and Steven A. Ballmer, his counterpart at Microsoft, for the first time attended an annual advertising industry meeting, the Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival.

headline.main: Foes No More, Ad Agencies Unite With Internet Firms
